title: 1. Installation
text: stable version package available CRAN servers, means can install regular install.packages() function. reason, installlation CRAN fails, might need look alternative methods.
code: install.packages("rgplates")

title: 1. Installation
text: can install package source directly GitHub using [devtools](https://cran.r-project.org/package=devtools) package. need install devtools run line code:
code: devtools::install_github("gplates/rgplates")

title: 1. Installation
text: sake completeness simplicity, sources stable version also deposited Zenodo. install.packages() function can used install source (although might install dependencies package. )
code: install.packages(     "https://zenodo.org/record/10614722/files/rgplates_0.4.0.tar.gz?download=1",      repos=NULL, type="source")

title: 1. Installation
text: encounter technical problems package described anywhere, might want take look development version.

title: 1. Installation
text: simples way install -development version via devtools package. just indicate want install -development devel branch.
code: devtools::install_github("gplates/rgplates@devel")

title: 1. Installation
text: wish install development version, recommend manual installation: 1. Clone repository local hard drive. 2. Open terminal navigate directory cloned. rgplates directory visible . 3. Run line terminal see error suggesting R found, add PATH environmental variable. R packages rgplates depend installed, install manually, get error. can also use devtools install development version :
code: R CMD INSTALL rgplates

title: 2. Reconstructions using modern coordinates (online)
text: paleocoordinate rotations executed reconstruct() function. default model used Merdith et al. 2021, described . (look reference reconstruct(), can see default model="MERDITH2021"). Every tectonic model relies plates, rotated surface Earth. Plate positions) can reconstructed age model covers. present-day positions plates can queried reconstruct() function, string passed (static_plates plate_polygons, depending model) first argument, target age set 0 (Ma). rgplates package relies sf handle vector spatial data - like plates. can anything normally can sf object: manipulate , change map projection, export use calculations. data standard equirectangular projection, registered longitude latitude data WGS84 Coordinate Reference System. can plot distribution plates plot() function. focus spatial data attributes features (technical nature), can plot geometries object.  Setting age argument allows access state plate tectonic configuration past points time. age argument accepts dates millions years. reconstruct position plates around Early/Late Cretaceous boundary (approx. 100Ma), set age argument 100: can plot results similar way:
code: pl0 <- reconstruct("static_polygons", age=0) pl0 #> Simple feature collection with 2391 features and 0 fields #> Geometry type: POLYGON #> Dimension:     XY #> Bounding box:  xmin: -179.99 ymin: -89.99 xmax: 179.99 ymax: 89.99 #> Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84 #> First 10 features: #>                          geometry #> 1  POLYGON ((112.0797 39.2348,... #> 2  POLYGON ((119.2562 36.6774,... #> 3  POLYGON ((130.47 41.99, 130... #> 4  POLYGON ((104.7254 40.4621,... #> 5  POLYGON ((102.6257 37.6989,... #> 6  POLYGON ((104.6209 38.9799,... #> 7  POLYGON ((94.0783 73.2609, ... #> 8  POLYGON ((122.0576 66.9608,... #> 9  POLYGON ((119.9099 61.8243,... #> 10 POLYGON ((105.7441 72.3461,... plot(pl0$geometry) pl100 <- reconstruct("static_polygons", age=100) pl100 #> Simple feature collection with 1042 features and 0 fields #> Geometry type: POLYGON #> Dimension:     XY #> Bounding box:  xmin: -179.99 ymin: -89.99 xmax: 179.99 ymax: 89.99 #> Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84 #> First 10 features: #>                          geometry #> 1  POLYGON ((123.8607 43.0607,... #> 2  POLYGON ((131.9549 41.4295,... #> 3  POLYGON ((142.9576 47.937, ... #> 4  POLYGON ((115.9434 43.2923,... #> 5  POLYGON ((114.4442 40.2853,... #> 6  POLYGON ((116.192 41.8191, ... #> 7  POLYGON ((84.8005 73.1575, ... #> 8  POLYGON ((121.8271 71.3283,... #> 9  POLYGON ((123.7043 66.1533,... #> 10 POLYGON ((97.0729 73.9899, ... plot(pl100$geometry)

title: 2. Reconstructions using modern coordinates (online)
text: Note result includes oceanic plates well, can quite distracting want visualize past distribution continents. help , paleogeographic positions present-day coastlines (plate margins) can quite helpful, can accessed, providing "coastlines" first argument reconstruct() function: can visalize way:  , pl0 pl100 c100 objects sf-class objects. can customize plotting sf object - instance setting fill color polygons plotting boundaries.  can easily plot top :
code: c0 <- reconstruct("coastlines", age=0) c100 <- reconstruct("coastlines", age=100) c100 #> Simple feature collection with 2451 features and 0 fields #> Geometry type: POLYGON #> Dimension:     XY #> Bounding box:  xmin: -179.99 ymin: -89.3928 xmax: 179.99 ymax: 83.1004 #> Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84 #> First 10 features: #>                          geometry #> 1  POLYGON ((132.3511 47.0744,... #> 2  POLYGON ((141.963 46.5718, ... #> 3  POLYGON ((134.1119 44.0571,... #> 4  POLYGON ((134.1819 42.4726,... #> 5  POLYGON ((133.5996 44.4895,... #> 6  POLYGON ((142.7117 48.1375,... #> 7  POLYGON ((133.7077 44.7113,... #> 8  POLYGON ((133.5384 44.3543,... #> 9  POLYGON ((132.7962 42.5404,... #> 10 POLYGON ((132.486 42.1309, ... plot(c100$geometry) plot(pl100$geometry, col="gray", border=NA) plot(pl100$geometry, col="gray", border=NA) plot(c100$geometry, col="darkgray", border=NA, add=TRUE)

title: 2. Reconstructions using modern coordinates (online)
text: Let’s consider location London (Google maps)! Either URL, user interface Google maps, can find coordinates city center around 51.52°N (latitude) 0.38°W (longitude). figure city Triassic/Jurassic boundary need : (1) register coordinates R; (2) provide reconstruct() function. Note dealing global-scale, approximate coordinates . precise results, always make sure CRS points matching CRS maps (including ellipses)! usually used equirectangular projection x-axis plotting become longitude, y axis becomes latitude, usually register coordinates order longitude first, latitude second (easting longitudes northing latitudes registered positive values). make structure absolutely clear, best register coordinates 2-column matrices, longitude first, latitude second column: Since coordinate reference system (CRS) maps longitude-latitude, can use coordinates directly indicate positionx city present-day map using points() - case red plus signs:
code: # the coordinates london <- c(-0.38, 51.52)  # make it a matrix londonMat <- matrix(london, ncol=2, byrow=TRUE)  # add column names (optional) colnames(londonMat) <- c("long", "lat") londonMat #>       long   lat #> [1,] -0.38 51.52 plot(c0$geometry) points(londonMat, col="red", pch=3)

title: 2. Reconstructions using modern coordinates (online)
text: Finding paleocoordinates localities easy calculating plates. use matrix defined earlier (londonMat) first argument, reconstruct() ("static_polygons" "coastlines" given earlier), provide target age million years: result calculation similar matrix: now including paleolongitude paleolatitude columns. provide coordinates plain matrix, coordinates inferred longitude latitude. can visualize way, visualized present-day position location:
code: londonMat100 <- reconstruct(londonMat, age=100) londonMat100 #>      paleolong paleolat #> [1,]    16.501  43.4247 plot(pl100$geometry, col="gray", border=NA) points(londonMat100, col="red", pch=3)

title: 2. Reconstructions using modern coordinates (online)
text: want reconstruct multiple locations, need provide rows matrix. instance, also want calculate positions Sydney, AU (33.85°S, 151.11°E) Montréal (CA) (45.52°N, 73.61°W), need add similar fashion. Now matrix longitudes latitudes, need use first argument reconstruct() function: Note order entities remains . can plot way similar single city.
code: # coordinates of the two other cities sydney<- c(151.17, -33.85) montreal<- c(-73.61, 45.52)  # all cities in a single matrix cities<- rbind(london, sydney, montreal)  #optional column names colnames(cities) <- c("long", "lat") cities #>            long    lat #> london    -0.38  51.52 #> sydney   151.17 -33.85 #> montreal -73.61  45.52 cities100 <- reconstruct(cities, age=100) cities100 #>          paleolong paleolat #> london     16.5010  43.4247 #> sydney    168.1989 -64.7057 #> montreal  -24.3468  43.0799 # the background map plot(c100$geometry, col="gray", border=NA)  # the reconstructed cities  points(cities100, col="red", pch=3)

title: 2. Reconstructions using modern coordinates (online)
text: look Details reference reconstruct(), see model argument can set character strings besides "MERDITH2021". indicate models accessible via GPLates Web Service. instance, want execute calculations reconstruct position position plates 100Ma, Seton et al. 2012 model, set model="SETON2012": can compare Merdith et al. model, plotting result top transparency (e.g. semi-transparent red, HTML RGBA: "#FF000077"):  can see two reconstructions differ quite bit, becomes apparent go back time. Also, transparency, can see plates overlap convergent zones.
code: c100seton <- reconstruct("coastlines", age=100, model="SETON2012") c100seton #> Simple feature collection with 1893 features and 0 fields #> Geometry type: POLYGON #> Dimension:     XY #> Bounding box:  xmin: -179.99 ymin: -89.99 xmax: 179.99 ymax: 85.6335 #> Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84 #> First 10 features: #>                          geometry #> 1  POLYGON ((-10.7862 27.3367,... #> 2  POLYGON ((-141.3289 -23.446... #> 3  POLYGON ((-60.5945 5.9602, ... #> 4  POLYGON ((-59.9848 4.8269, ... #> 5  POLYGON ((-36.5397 16.789, ... #> 6  POLYGON ((-36.7068 16.8855,... #> 7  POLYGON ((-36.494 16.7124, ... #> 8  POLYGON ((-36.3418 16.5887,... #> 9  POLYGON ((-12.5495 22.9016,... #> 10 POLYGON ((-10.4138 22.3064,... plot(c100$geometry, col="gray", border=NA) plot(c100seton$geometry, col="#FF000077", add=TRUE, border=NA)

title: 3. Reconstructions based on given paleocoordinates (online)
text: Let’s work Triassic (220Ma) using default "MERDITH2021" model! can reconstruct positions present-day coastlines saw earlier can also plot way:  Working reconstruction often involves defining points paleocoordinate system: either represent notable geographic positions, results geometric transformations. Since map using WGS84 Coordinate Reference System (CRS), can visualize positions points():  can calculate present-day positions points reconstruct() function - indicate coordinates given age, case 220Ma: Note warning message! reads bit technical, key bit first bullet point: points probably partitioning polygons. simply means calculating present-day positions simply possible paleocoordinates assigned plates present model time indicated argument. points indicated missing values (NAs`) returned object present-day coordinates. result indicates point named "three" (coordinates -60 30) probably plates. can confirm looking plates (static_polygons "MERDITH2021" model). can queried : … plotted top existing map :  point question indeed fall plates.
code: coast220 <- reconstruct("coastlines", age=220) coast220 #> Simple feature collection with 2219 features and 0 fields #> Geometry type: POLYGON #> Dimension:     XY #> Bounding box:  xmin: -179.99 ymin: -82.3516 xmax: 179.99 ymax: 89.99 #> Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84 #> First 10 features: #>                          geometry #> 1  POLYGON ((164.7667 58.5746,... #> 2  POLYGON ((171.5001 53.1643,... #> 3  POLYGON ((162.0057 55.6797,... #> 4  POLYGON ((160.0406 54.5613,... #> 5  POLYGON ((162.1421 56.2415,... #> 6  POLYGON ((174.0752 53.7632,... #> 7  POLYGON ((162.533 56.3312, ... #> 8  POLYGON ((161.9085 56.184, ... #> 9  POLYGON ((158.8934 55.3449,... #> 10 POLYGON ((158.0967 55.2248,... # the background map plot(coast220$geometry, col="gray", border=NA) # the coordinates one <- c(-15, -25) two <- c(100, -45) three <- c(-60, 30)  # make it a matrix posMat <- rbind(one, two, three)   # add column names (optional) colnames(posMat) <- c("paleolong", "paleolat") posMat #>       paleolong paleolat #> one         -15      -25 #> two         100      -45 #> three       -60       30 points(posMat, col="red", pch=3) presentPoints <- reconstruct(posMat, from=220) #> Warning in gwsReconstructPoints(coords = x[bPresent, , drop = FALSE], time = from, : Identical coordinates returned as present-day positions (4 digits):  #>   - Some points are probably off the partitioning polygons. #>   - Returning NAs for these. presentPoints #>           long      lat #> one   -57.5362 -12.9236 #> two   132.5350 -25.1888 #> three       NA       NA pl220 <- reconstruct("static_polygons", age=220) plot(pl220$geometry, col="#00555522", add=TRUE, border="#00555533")

title: 3. Reconstructions based on given paleocoordinates (online)
text: Keeping missing value points highly beneficial - helps us organize data efficiently. However, regularly work coordinates plates, warnings saw might somewhat disruptive. example, want find present-day coordiantes bunch points, coming tropics 220Ma: can visualize  can turn warnings plate assignment warn argument reconstruct(): missing values matrix indicate presence points static polygons: can use visualize points polygons - example ca circle previously plotted map:
code: # random points from the tropics, set seed to make them reproducible set.seed(0)  # note that these are not uniformly distributed in space! tropoints <- cbind(     paleolong=runif(200, -180, 180),     paleolat=runif(200, -30, 30) ) # static polygons from 220Ma  plot(pl220$geometry, col="#00555522", border="#00555533")  # points points(tropoints, pch=3) tropoints0 <- reconstruct(tropoints, from=220, warn=FALSE) # which present-day longitude values are missing?  # Prvodide row indices indMissing <- which(is.na(tropoints0[, 1])) # circle off-polygon points points(tropoints[indMissing,], pch=1, cex=2, col="red")

title: 3. Reconstructions based on given paleocoordinates (online)
text: Going back three points inspecting earlier (posMat): present-day coordinates given longitude (long) latitude (lat) values presentPoints matrix object. can visualize map WGS84 CRS. instance can grab coaslines "MERDITH2021" model, plot usual way  … use points put positions map:  Note missing values rendered.
code: # Present-day coastlines today coast0 <- reconstruct("coastlines", age=0) # Plot outlines plot(coast0$geometry, col="gray", border="darkgray") # Plot present-day positions of the points  points(presentPoints, col="red", pch=3)

title: 3. Reconstructions based on given paleocoordinates (online)
text: want calculate positions three points (least two actual plates), 10 million years earlier (.e. 230Ma), need change target age reconstruction. argument recontruct() defaults 0: date represents present. target age normally use calculating paleocoordinates present-day locations, providing argument well, can indicate given coordinates actually represent paleocoordinates. can visualize offset points calculating positions coastlines (earlier): … plotting information 220Ma 230Ma time interval figure, using different colors:  can visually evaluate offset two time intervals can use coordinates calculations.
code: # paleocoordinates of 220Ma rotated to 230Ma pm230 <- reconstruct(posMat, from=220, age=230, warn=FALSE) # paleocoordinates of 220Ma rotated to 230Ma coast230 <- reconstruct("coastlines", age=230) # 220Ma (gray and black) plot(coast220$geometry, col="gray", border=NA) points(posMat, col="black", pch=3)  # 230Ma (red) - use add to overlplot! plot(coast230$geometry, col="#BB000022", border=NA, add=TRUE) points(pm230, col="#BB0000", pch=3)

what: Tracing the points’ evolution to the present
title: 3. Reconstructions based on given paleocoordinates (online)
text: can reconstruct positions paleocoordinates single times, can multiple target ages iterating call reconstruct(). make easier, can provide set dates age argument, calculate paleo- (0) recent (=0) coordinates every given age. instance, want trace positions points present day (say steps 10Ma), need provide vector multiple target ages: default behavior function return list results: one every target age - running reconstruct() separately target ages: individual elements list objects results previous calls reconstruct(). names list include target ages coordinates represent. might structure efficient - might also cases need access coordinates point different times quickly. purpose, array representation results might better suited, can toggle setting listout argument FALSE default (listout=TRUE): Accessing structure object simple way inform access desired subsets: object three-dimensional array coordinates, target ages given first dimension (rows), points second (columns) coordinate type (paleolong paleolat) third (planes). instance, want access history point one can use character subscripts coordinates ages simple 2D matrix: can use matrices display rotation history points 220Ma present day:  constitutes overview online method reconstruction.
code: # vector of target ages (steps of 10Ma) allAges <- seq(220, 0, -10)  # run the reconstruction # will take a couple seconds pmHistoryList <- reconstruct(posMat, from=220, age=allAges, warn=FALSE) # first 6 elements of the list head(pmHistoryList) #> $`220` #>       paleolong paleolat #> one         -15      -25 #> two         100      -45 #> three        NA       NA #>  #> $`210` #>       paleolong paleolat #> one    -13.8011 -23.8324 #> two     98.0900 -43.2016 #> three        NA       NA #>  #> $`200` #>       paleolong paleolat #> one    -13.2429 -21.3120 #> two     96.4196 -44.1218 #> three        NA       NA #>  #> $`190` #>       paleolong paleolat #> one    -13.1015 -19.5392 #> two     95.4666 -45.4731 #> three        NA       NA #>  #> $`180` #>       paleolong paleolat #> one    -13.5507 -17.7555 #> two     95.1759 -48.7927 #> three        NA       NA #>  #> $`170` #>       paleolong paleolat #> one    -14.4549 -16.2838 #> two     97.6837 -54.2356 #> three        NA       NA pmHistory <- reconstruct(posMat, from=220,   age=allAges, warn=FALSE, listout=FALSE) str(pmHistory) #>  num [1:23, 1:3, 1:2] -15 -13.8 -13.2 -13.1 -13.6 ... #>  - attr(*, "dimnames")=List of 3 #>   ..$ : chr [1:23] "220" "210" "200" "190" ... #>   ..$ : chr [1:3] "one" "two" "three" #>   ..$ : chr [1:2] "paleolong" "paleolat" # history of point 'one'  oneHistory <- pmHistory[, "one", ] twoHistory <- pmHistory[, "two", ] # redraw 220ma map plot(coast220$geometry, col="gray", border=NA)  # the 220Ma position of point 'two' points(posMat, col="black", pch=3)  #  present-day coastlines plot(coast0$geometry, col="#0000DD22", border=NA, add=TRUE)  # the 220Ma positions points(presentPoints, col="#0000DD", pch=3)  # tracing lines lines(oneHistory, col="#0000DD99", type="o", cex=0.3, pch=16) lines(twoHistory, col="#0000DD99", type="o", cex=0.3, pch=16)

title: 3. Offline reconstruction
text: Instead relying connections GPlates Web Service, offline method, allows execute plate tectonic rotations locally, computer. , need two things present computer besides rgplates package: GPlates desktop application, calculate reconstructions actual tectonic model files, reconstructions .

title: 3. Offline reconstruction
text: GPlates current standard program used build, manipulate employ plate tectonic reconstructions. GPlates well developed Graphical User Interface (GUI), can use indepenently anything tutorial. wish learn GPlates , can find lot material . leave R environment use GUI GPlates order use offline method ofrgplates. just make sure application installed computer, rgplates take care rest.

title: 3. Offline reconstruction
text: Besides installing rgplates package, install GPlates Desktop Application computer. seeing file need operating system, scroll bottom page, select file wish download follow instructions. tested major operating systems (Windows, Mac, GNU/Linux), working reliably GPlates versions v2.2 v2.3. rgplates able find GPlates installation Mac GNU/Linux box. also issues Windows, long install GPlates default installation directory (change suggested installation - unless asking trouble!).

title: 3. Offline reconstruction
text: use offline method, tectonic model computer. Actually, thing plate tectonic model. technical point view, every model consists least two data items: Partitioning polygons Reconstruction tree (aka. rotation file) partitioning polygons vector spatial data (polygons) represent present-day distribution tectonic plates. GPlates moves polygons surface Earth rotations described reconstruction tree. typically developed together (usually refer model), stored separately different files. words, GPlates program execute rotations/reconstructions, also need files online method relies files servers GPlates Web Service. instance, partitioning polygons PaleoMAP model visible just ask "plates", present-day age (.e. 0Ma).  order use offline method need partitioning polygons reconstruction tree computer, represent R, pass reconstruct() function.
code: # attaching the package is necesary for both methods library(rgplates) #> Loading required package: sf #> Linking to GEOS 3.10.2, GDAL 3.4.1, PROJ 8.2.1; sf_use_s2() is TRUE # this is still the online method: partPol<- reconstruct("static_polygons", age=0)  # these are the partitioning polyongs visualized plot(partPol$geometry)

title: 3. Offline reconstruction
text: sake making first trial simple, using model files PaleoMAP project, distributed rgplates package. files package’s install directory zip archive. : Create new temporary directory store model files Unzip model files load R. Note: even simpler ways get files represent R ways (chronosphere, look Tutorial 4.) didactic purposes, recommend first way follows.

title: 3. Offline reconstruction
text: Temporary directories best places store transient data, files, created cacluation necessary outside R session (course don’t need store , can use directory computer). Temporary directories easy create, just use tempdir() function, create directory , also tell find : operating system handles differently, don’t surprised don’t match result - actually, likely different every session run function .
code: td <- tempdir() td #> [1] "/tmp/RtmpOkFl1j"

title: 3. Offline reconstruction
text: files model quite big, bigger recommended CRAN guidelines, compressed. unzip using unzip() function - first find . path R packages’ installation can found using system.file() function. can confirm right path listing contents directory list.files() model data extdata directory, archive paleomap_v3.zip. locate archive extract temporary directory (exdir argument) can confirm extraction indeed happened looking temporary directory: two files important us: one ends .gpml (static plate polygons GPlates Markup Language format) one ends .rot (reconstruction tree/rotation file). know absolute paths files, can found :
code: # the path to the rgplates package rgPath <- system.file(package="rgplates") list.files(rgPath) #>  [1] "CITATION"    "data"        "DESCRIPTION" "extdata"     "help"        #>  [6] "html"        "INDEX"       "LICENSE"     "Meta"        "NAMESPACE"   #> [11] "NEWS.md"     "R" unzip(file.path(rgPath,"extdata/paleomap_v3.zip"), exdir=td) list.files(file.path(td)) #>  [1] "file20e37148a4e5"                  "file20e371b1dda9a"                 #>  [3] "file20e3729f1e688"                 "file20e3734f22df7"                 #>  [5] "file20e3755a5ee8c"                 "file20e3766b4889a"                 #>  [7] "PALEOMAP_PlateModel.rot"           "PALEOMAP_PlatePolygons.gpml"       #>  [9] "PALEOMAP_PoliticalBoundaries.gpml" "rmarkdown-str20e3724dd2b86.html" pathToPolygons <- file.path(td, "PALEOMAP_PlatePolygons.gpml") pathToPolygons #> [1] "/tmp/RtmpOkFl1j/PALEOMAP_PlatePolygons.gpml" pathToRotations <- file.path(td, "PALEOMAP_PlateModel.rot") pathToRotations #> [1] "/tmp/RtmpOkFl1j/PALEOMAP_PlateModel.rot"

title: 3. Offline reconstruction
text: Now files know find , represent R way, can indicate want used GPlates plate tectonic reconstructions. need create platemodel class object just . need provide, paths files. rotation file special place platemodel object, provided separately. static plate polygons become feature collection, named. make interface behave way online method called "static_polygons": platemodel-class object, actually nothing else thin wrapper includes files actually located. Now great time mention true flexibility offline method lies. can use third party model files , long provide appropriate absolute paths files, methods follow work. See
code: pm <- platemodel(     features=c("static_polygons"=pathToPolygons),     rotation=pathToRotations ) pm #> GPlates plate tectonic model. #> rotation:                      "PALEOMAP_PlateModel.rot"  #> static_polygons:               "PALEOMAP_PlatePolygons.gpml"

title: 3. Offline reconstruction
text: recontruction works way, online method, difference instead using string model argument (defaults "MERDITH2021"), use platemodel-class object pm. plates reconstructed 100Ma PaleoMAP model - now calculated offline method: Note similar sf class object saw earlier online method, although somewhat attributes. Nevertheless, can visualize way, using plot().
code: plOff100 <- reconstruct("static_polygons", age=100, model=pm) plOff100 #> Simple feature collection with 176 features and 17 fields #> Geometry type: GEOMETRY #> Dimension:     XY #> Bounding box:  xmin: -180 ymin: -90 xmax: 180 ymax: 90 #> Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84 #> First 10 features: #>    APPEARANCE DISAPPEARA PlateID NAME DESCR PLATEID2               GPGIM_TYPE #> 1           0          0     307 <NA>  <NA>        0 gpml:UnclassifiedFeature #> 2           0          0     317 <NA>  <NA>        0 gpml:UnclassifiedFeature #> 3           0          0     318 <NA>  <NA>        0 gpml:UnclassifiedFeature #> 4           0          0     318 <NA>  <NA>        0 gpml:UnclassifiedFeature #> 5           0          0     324 <NA>  <NA>        0 gpml:UnclassifiedFeature #> 6           0          0     325 <NA>  <NA>        0 gpml:UnclassifiedFeature #> 7           0          0     326 <NA>  <NA>        0 gpml:UnclassifiedFeature #> 8           0          0     327 <NA>  <NA> title: 3. Offline reconstruction
text: Reconstructing positions points similar online method. , difference provide platemodel object model argument. example earlier calculate visualize past positions cities, now offline method: First, get data localities: Second, reconstruct model plot:  Note: order , plateID needs assigned every point. use partitioning argument select feature collection platemodel object used partitioning polygons. defaults "static_polygons" (check documentation reconstruct()!), say anything . platemodel objects, might need set explicitly!
code: london <- c(-0.38, 51.52) sydney<- c(151.17, -33.85) montreal<- c(-73.61, 45.52)  # all cities in a single matrix cities<- rbind(london, sydney, montreal)  #optional column names colnames(cities) <- c("long", "lat") cities #>            long    lat #> london    -0.38  51.52 #> sydney   151.17 -33.85 #> montreal -73.61  45.52 cities100 <- reconstruct(cities, age=100, model=pm) cities100 #>           paleolong  paleolat #> london     1.550889  39.94383 #> sydney   144.703860 -64.28464 #> montreal -35.631821  37.69961 # the background map plot(plOff100$geometry, col="gray", border=NA)  # the reconstructed cities  points(cities100, col="red", pch=3)

what: Alternative ways to get model files
title: 3. Offline reconstruction
text: model files available EarthByte Resources page. instance, files PaleoMAP model used , available : https://www.earthbyte.org/paleomap-paleoatlas--gplates/. bottom page, find single link : Link rasters, reconstruction files tutorial allow download Scotese_Paleoatlas_v3.zip file. zip file, directory PALEOMAP Global Plate Model, can see files earlier: contents archive can use , similar files create platemodel objects, long provide absolute paths files.

title: 3. Offline reconstruction
text: can see, handling files quite tedious, , developers rgplates, barely ever use way. practical applications recommend using offline method rgplates chronosphere, can learn next tutorial: 5. Reconstructions chronosphere.

title: 5. Reconstruction with data from the chronosphere
text: highly optimized workflow, rgplates chronosphere R package required.
code: library(rgplates) #> Loading required package: sf #> Linking to GEOS 3.10.2, GDAL 3.4.1, PROJ 8.2.1; sf_use_s2() is TRUE library(chronosphere) #> Chronosphere - Evolving Earth System Variables #> Important: never fetch data as a superuser / with admin. privileges! #>  #> Note that the package was split for efficient maintenance and development: #>  - Plate tectonic calculations -> package 'rgplates' #>  - Arrays of raster and vector spatials -> package 'via'

title: 5. Reconstruction with data from the chronosphere
text: Detailed tutorials made available later use chronosphere-portal. now, need know, access platemodel-class objects. Downloading data iwth chronosphere easy: need single line code, appropriate IDs data choice. following expression download detailed tectonic model (feature collections reconstruction tree) used Merdith et al. 2021: arguments chronosphere::fetch() source (src), series (ser) version (ver) ID item want download.  tectonic model additional feature collections can reconstructed demand. make use platemodel class straightforward, also includes information feature collections’ time frame validity.
code: pm <- chronosphere::fetch(src="GPlates", ser="MERDITH2021") #>  #> ------------------------------------------------------------ #> Accessing chronosphere registry tables. #> ------------------------------------------------------------ #> Downloading registry tables. #>  #> ------------------------------------------------------------ #> Item no. 717, src:GPlates, ser: MERDITH2021, ver: 1.1, res: NA. #> ------------------------------------------------------------ #>  #> ------------------------------------------------------------ #> Downloading import code. #> ------------------------------------------------------------ #>  #> ------------------------------------------------------------ #> Downloading data file. #> ------------------------------------------------------------ #> MD5 checksum passed. #> Attaching package 'rgplates'. #>  #> If you use the data in publications, please cite its #> reference(s), as well as that of the 'chronosphere' project. #> Merdith, Andrew S., Simon E. Williams, Alan S. Collins, Michael G. Tetley, Jacob A. Mulder, Morgan L. Blades, Alexander Young, et al. 2021. “Extending Full-Plate Tectonic Models into Deep Time: Linking the Neoproterozoic and the Phanerozoic.” Earth-Science Reviews 214 (March): 103477. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.earscirev.2020.103477. #> Merdith, Andrew. 2020. “Plate model for ’Extending Full-Plate Tectonic Models into Deep Time: Linking the Neoproterozoic and the Phanerozoic ’.” Zenodo. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.4485738. pm #> GPlates plate tectonic model. #> rotation:                      "1000_0_rotfile_Merdith_et_al.rot"  #> static_polygons:               "shapes_static_polygons_Merdith_et_al.gpml" #> cratons:                       "shapes_cratons_Merdith_et_al.gpml" #> continents:                    "shapes_continents_Merdith_et_al.gpml" #> coastlines:                    "shapes_coastlines_Merdith_et_al.gpml" #> plate_boundaries_250:          "250-0_plate_boundaries_Merdith_et_al.gpml" #> plate_boundaries_410:          "410-250_plate_boundaries_Merdith_et_al.gpml" #> convergence:                   "1000-410-Convergence_Merdith_et_al.gpml" #> divergence:                    "1000-410-Divergence_Merdith_et_al.gpml" #> topologies:                    "1000-410-Topologies_Merdith_et_al.gpml" #> transforms:                    "1000-410-Transforms_Merdith_et_al.gpml" #> topology-building-blocks:      "TopologyBuildingBlocks_Merdith_et_al.gpml" #> poles:                         "1000-410_poles.gpml"

title: 5. Reconstruction with data from the chronosphere
text: model can used offline reconstruction method (need GPlates installed !). Names feature collections can passed subject reconstruction. instance get "static_polygons" feature collection use: includes static plate polygons existed 100Ma. can plotted :  Additional feature collections can reconstructed just easily. instance, interested positions continental plates ("continents") reconstructed positions present-day coastlines ("coastlines"), respectively: can plot top original maps :
code: # reconstruct the plates and plot them pl100<- rgplates::reconstruct("static_polygons", age=100, model=pm) plot(pl100$geometry, col="gray70", border=NA) continents100 <- rgplates::reconstruct("continents", age=100, model=pm) coastlines100 <- rgplates::reconstruct("coastlines", age=100, model=pm) plot(continents100$geometry, col="#bc683a", border=NA, add=TRUE) plot(coastlines100$geometry, col="#63351c", border=NA, add=TRUE)

title: 5. Reconstruction with data from the chronosphere
text: ! couple lines code, can download tectonic information, calculate rotations plot reconstructed geometries. Simple. originally intended use reconstruct() function’s offline method, recommend adopt general workflow. Note intend add many models chronosphere, recently overhauled make flexible useful possible. interested tutorials, keep eye open Evolv-ED blog, intend deposit additional guides integrate rgplates complex analytical pipelines.

title: R Interface for the GPlates Web Service and Desktop Application
text: Functions GPlates Web Service GPlates Desktop Application allow users reconstruct past positions geographic entities based user-selected rotation models without leaving R running environment.  online reconstruction (GPlates Web Service) makes rotation static plates, coastlines, low number geographic coordinates available using nothing internet connection. offline reconstruction requires external installation GPlates Desktop Application, allows efficient batch rotation thousands coordinates, Simple Features (sf) Spatial (sp) objects custom reconstruction trees partitioning polygons. Examples plate tectonic models accessible via chronosphere.

title: R Interface for the GPlates Web Service and Desktop Application
text: can reconstruct positions plates 65 Ma using Merdith et al. 2021 model transform Mollweide projection using chunk code:
code: library(rgplates)  # Rotation of plates using the GPlates Web Service coastlines <- reconstruct("coastlines", age=65, model="MERDITH2021")  # the edge of the map (for mollweide) edge <- mapedge()  # transform to Mollweide epsg <- "ESRI:54009" coastsMoll <- sf::st_transform(coastlines, crs=epsg) edgeMoll <- sf::st_transform(edge, crs=epsg)  # plot plot(edgeMoll, col="#1A6BB0", border="gray30") plot(coastsMoll, border=NA, col="gray90", add=TRUE)

title: R Interface for the GPlates Web Service and Desktop Application
text: functions originally developed published part chronosphere R package. better compliance UNIX philosophy efficient distribution/development, original chronosphere broken three R packages: chronosphere: version-controlled data distribution. rgplates: functions related tectonic reconstructions. via: Virtual Arrays efficient organisation high-dimensional data. beta version, like R, comes absolutely warranty.

title: R Interface for the GPlates Web Service and Desktop Application
text: package developed make R-based analyses require paloecoordinate rotations easier implement, .e. applying rotation model - replacement tools dedidacted complex paleogeographic reconstruction model development. complex analyses welcome check gplately pyGPlates, awesome python packages developed GPlates team.

text: data.frame 4 variables 17 observations.

title: Valid reconstructable feature collections of the GPlates Web Service — gws
text: valid return combinations selected models feature collections copied https://gwsdoc.gplates.org/models. model name reconstruction model. feature name feature collection. oldest reconstruction age accepted model return feature collection. youngest reconstruction age accepted model return feature collection.

what: Return and set the remote URL for the GPlates Web Service — getgws
title: Return and set the remote URL for the GPlates Web Service — getgws
text: set functions allows configuration remote URL, R client package can used different instance GPlates web service, including local implementation (served localhost). function use http get method access version number GPlates Web Service.

title: Return and set the remote URL for the GPlates Web Service — getgws
code: getgws()  setgws(url = "", check = TRUE, reset = FALSE, silent = FALSE)  checkgws(silent = FALSE)

title: Return and set the remote URL for the GPlates Web Service — getgws
text: url (character) single string specifying URL GPlates Web Service (trailing slash). check (logical) Flag specify whether immediate querying GWS performed? fails url set! reset (logical) Flag specify whether factory default reset. silent Logical flag indicating wheth output silent?

title: Return and set the remote URL for the GPlates Web Service — getgws
text: getws returns single character string URL GWS. Invisible return, either FALSE, character string version number.

title: Return and set the remote URL for the GPlates Web Service — getgws
text: getws function returns current url GPLates Web Service (defaults : https://gws.gplates.org/). setws function allows setting GPLates Web Service URL.

title: Return and set the remote URL for the GPlates Web Service — getgws
code: # Access currently set remote URL. getgws() #> [1] "https://gws.gplates.org/" # In case you have the GWS running on localhost (default port 18000): # At time of writing this, the local instance does not return version, checking # does not work! setgws("http://localhost:18000/", check=FALSE) # To reset factory defaults setgws(reset=TRUE, check=FALSE)

what: Function to quickly draft the edge of the equirectangular projection — mapedge
title: Function to quickly draft the edge of the equirectangular projection — mapedge
text: Function plot edge map different projections.

title: Function to quickly draft the edge of the equirectangular projection — mapedge
code: mapedge(   x = 360,   y = 180,   xmin = -180,   xmax = 180,   ymin = -90,   ymax = 90,   out = "sf" )

title: Function to quickly draft the edge of the equirectangular projection — mapedge
text: x (numeric) Number segments x (longitude) dimension. y (numeric) Number segments y (latitude) dimension. xmin (numeric) Minimum value x (longitude). xmax (numeric) Minimum value x (longitude). ymin (numeric) Maximum value y (latitude). ymax (numeric) Maximum value y (latitude). (character) Output format, either "sf" "sp". default "sf" returns simple feature geometries, "sp" returns SpatialPolygons sp package.

title: Function to quickly draft the edge of the equirectangular projection — mapedge
text: sfc-, SpatialPolygons-class object.

title: Function to quickly draft the edge of the equirectangular projection — mapedge
code: # requires rgdal edge <- mapedge() molledge <- st_transform(edge, "ESRI:54009") plot(molledge)

what: Class of objects representing plate tectonic models — platemodel-class
title: Class of objects representing plate tectonic models — platemodel-class
text: Meta-object containing paths unique plate tectonic model

title: Class of objects representing plate tectonic models — platemodel-class
code: # S4 method for platemodel initialize(   .Object,   rotation = NULL,   features = NULL,   name = NULL,   polygons = NULL )

title: Class of objects representing plate tectonic models — platemodel-class
text: .Object Constructor argument (needed). rotation (character) path rotation file. features (character) Named vector features paths individual files. name (character) (Optional) name model. polygons (character) (Deprecated) path static plate polygon file.

title: Class of objects representing plate tectonic models — platemodel-class
text: platemodel class object.

title: Class of objects representing plate tectonic models — platemodel-class
code: # path to provided archive archive <- file.path(   system.file("extdata", package="rgplates"),    "paleomap_v3.zip") # extract to temporary directory unzip(archive, exdir=tempdir()) # path to the rotation file rotPath <- file.path(tempdir(),    "PALEOMAP_PlateModel.rot") # path to the polygons polPath <- file.path(tempdir(),    "PALEOMAP_PlatePolygons.gpml") # register in R - to be used in reconstruct() model <- platemodel(rotation=rotPath, features=c("static_polygons"=polPath))

title: Reconstruct geographic features — reconstruct
text: Reconstruct geographic locations present day coordinates spatial objects back paleo-positions.  location assigned plate id moved back time using chosen reconstruction model.

title: Reconstruct geographic features — reconstruct
code: reconstruct(x, ...)  # S4 method for matrix reconstruct(   x,   age = 0,   model = "MERDITH2021",   from = 0,   listout = TRUE,   verbose = FALSE,   enumerate = TRUE,   chunk = NULL,   reverse = FALSE,   path.gplates = NULL,   cleanup = TRUE,   dir = NULL,   plateperiod = NULL,   partitioning = "static_polygons",   check = TRUE,   warn = TRUE,   anchor = 0,   validtime = TRUE )  # S4 method for data.frame reconstruct(x, ...)  # S4 method for numeric reconstruct(x, ...)  # S4 method for character reconstruct(   x,   age,   model = "MERDITH2021",   listout = TRUE,   verbose = FALSE,   path.gplates = NULL,   cleanup = TRUE,   dir = NULL,   partitioning = "static_polygons",   check = TRUE,   anchor = 0 )  # S4 method for Spatial reconstruct(   x,   age,   model,   listout = TRUE,   verbose = FALSE,   path.gplates = NULL,   cleanup = TRUE,   dir = NULL,   plateperiod = NULL,   partitioning = "static_polygons",   check = TRUE,   validtime = TRUE )  # S4 method for sf reconstruct(   x,   age,   model,   listout = TRUE,   verbose = FALSE,   path.gplates = NULL,   cleanup = TRUE,   dir = NULL,   plateperiod = NULL,   gmeta = FALSE,   partitioning = "static_polygons",   check = TRUE,   validtime = TRUE )

title: Reconstruct geographic features — reconstruct
text: x features reconstructed. Can vector longitude latitude representing single point matrix/dataframe first column longitude second column latitude. online subroutine, character strings "static_polygons", "coastlines"  "plate_polygons" return static plate polygons, rotated present-day coastlines topological plates, respectively. offline subroutine, can name feature set defined model object. Spatial* sf classes also accepted, although input still experimental. ... arguments passed class-specific methods. age (numeric) target age Ma feature reconstructed. Defaults 0 Ma. model (character platemodel)  reconstruction model. class argument selects submodule used reconstruction, character value invoke remote reconstruction submodule submit x GPlates Web Service. platemodel class object call local-reconstruction submodule. default "PALEOMAP". See details available models. (numeric) original age features reconstructed. single value, defaults 0Ma. used online reconstruction module. listout (logical)multiple ages given, output can returned list listout = TRUE. verbose (logical) call URLs (remote submodule) console feedback (local-submodule) printed? enumerate (logical) coordinate/age combinations enumerated reconstructed (set TRUE default)? FALSE applicable number rows x equal number elementes age. point reconstructed age index age row coordinates x. List output available case. chunk (numeric) Deprected argument online reconstruction method. Ignored. reverse (logical) Argument remote reconstruction submodule. flag control direction reconstruction. reverse = TRUE, function  calculate present-day coordinates given paleo-coordinates, age setting target. recommended, kept compatibility GPlates Web Service. Using instead age automatically trigger reverse reconstruction. path.gplates (character) Argument local reconstruction submodule. case GPlates executable file found coded default location, full path executable (gplates-<ver>.exe Windows) can entered . e.g. "C:/gplates_2.3.0_win64/gplates.exe". cleanup (logical) Argument local reconstruction submodule. temporary files deleted immediately reconstructions? dir (character) Argument local reconstruction submodule. Directory temporary files reconstruction stored (defaults temporary directory created R). Remember toggle cleanup want see files. plateperiod (logical) Deprecated argument, renamed validtime higher compatibility GPlates Web Service. partitioning (character) Argument local reconstruction submodule, feature collection tectonic model used assing plate IDs features? defaults "static_polygons". check (logical) validity entries GWS checked information stored gws? (default: TRUE) warn (character) Argument online reconstruction submodule, used reverse-reconstructions (calculation present-day coordinates paleocoordinates). set `TRUE` (default), function produce warning paleocoordinates assigned paritioning polygons (missing values returned ). set `FALSE`, warnings displayed. anchor (character) Argument online reconstruction submodule. Plate ID anchored plate. 'anchored_plate_id' parameter GPlates Web Service. validtime (logical) Argument local reconstuction submodule. durations plates forced partitioned feature? set TRUE plate duration estimates long, might lose data. inverse ignore.valid.time argument GWS. gmeta (logical) Argument local reconstruction submodule, case, sf objects supplied. metadata produced GPlates included output object?

title: Reconstruct geographic features — reconstruct
text: numeric matrix x numeric, matrix data.frame, Spatial* class objects, depending input. NULL case model specified.

title: Reconstruct geographic features — reconstruct
text: function implements two reconstruction submodules, selected model argument: model character entry, reconstruct() function uses GPlates Web Service (https://gwsdoc.gplates.org/, remote reconstruction submodule). available reconstruction models submodule (2024-02-02): "TorsvikCocks2017" (Torsvik Cocks, 2017) coastlines (0-540 Ma). Uses mantle reference frame default. climatically sensitive analyses use paleomagnetic reference frame, can toggle setting anchor parameter 1 default 0. "SETON2012" (Seton et al., 2012) coastlines topological plate polygons (0-200 Ma). "RODINIA2013" (Li et al., 2012) coastlines (530-1100 Ma). "MULLER2016" (Muller et al., 2016) coastlines topological plate polygons (0-230 Ma). "GOLONKA" (Wright et al. 2013) coastlines (0-550 Ma). "PALEOMAP" (Scotese, 2016) coastlines (0-1100 Ma). "MATTHEWS2016_mantle_ref" (Matthews et al., 2016) coastlines topological plate polygons (0-410 Ma). "MATTHEWS2016_pmag_ref" (Matthews et al., 2016) coastlines topological plate polygons (0-410 Ma). "MULLER2019" (Müller et al., 2019) coastlines static plate polygons. (0-250 Ma). "MERDITH2021" (Merdith et al., 2021, default) coastlines static plate polygons (0-1000 Ma). "MULLER2022" (Müller et al., 2022) coastlines static plate polygons (0-1000 Ma). model platemodel class object, function try use GPLates desktop application (https://www.gplates.org/) reconstruct coordinates (local reconstruction submodule). Plate models available chronosphere fetch function. See datasets available models. function try find main GPlates executable default installation directory. succeed, use path.gplates enter full path GPlates executable character string.

title: Reconstruct geographic features — reconstruct
text: Matthews, K. J., Maloney, K. T., Zahirovic, S., Williams, S. E., Seton, M., & Müller, R. D. (2016). Global plate boundary evolution kinematics since late Paleozoic. Global Planetary Change, 146, 226–250. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.gloplacha.2016.10.002  Andrew S. Merdith, Simon E. Williams, Alan S. Collins, Michael G. Tetley, Jacob . Mulder, Morgan L. Blades, Alexander Young, Sheree E. Armistead, John Cannon, Sabin Zahirovic, R. Dietmar Müller, (2021). Extending full-plate tectonic models deep time: Linking Neoproterozoic Phanerozoic, Earth-Science Reviews, Volume 214, 2021, 103477, ISSN 0012-8252, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.earscirev.2020.103477.  Müller, R. D., Seton, M., Zahirovic, S., Williams, S. E., Matthews, K. J., Wright, N. M., … Cannon, J. (2016). Ocean Basin Evolution Global-Scale Plate Reorganization Events Since Pangea Breakup. title: Reconstruct geographic features — reconstruct
code: # With the web service  # simple matrices # replace model with desired choice reconstruct(matrix(c(95, 54), nrow=1), 140, model=NULL) #> No model was specified. #> NULL  # points reconstruction xy <-cbind(long=c(95,142), lat=c(54, -33)) reconstruct(xy, 140, model=NULL) #> No model was specified. #> NULL

what: R Interface for the GPlates Web Service and Desktop Application — rgplates
title: R Interface for the GPlates Web Service and Desktop Application — rgplates
text: Query functions GPlates <https://www.gplates.org/> Desktop Application GPlates Web Service <https://gws.gplates.org/> allow users reconstruct coordinates, static plates, Simple Features Spatial objects without leaving R running environment. R extension developed umbrella DFG (Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft) Research Unit TERSANE2 (2332, TEmperature Related Stressors ANcient Extinctions).

title: R Interface for the GPlates Web Service and Desktop Application — rgplates
text: still Beta version. R, free software comes ABSOLUTELY WARRANTY. Nevertheless, notes found bugs suggestions welcome.

title: R Interface for the GPlates Web Service and Desktop Application — rgplates
text: Adam T. Kocsis (adam.t.kocsis@gmail.com), Nussaibah B. Raja Simon Williams

title: rgplates 0.4.1 - 2024-08-09
text: checkgws(), getgws() setgws() functions allow customization remote location GPlates Web Service.

title: rgplates 0.4.1 - 2024-08-09
text: Docs updated reflect repo transfer https://github.com/gplates

title: rgplates 0.4.0 - 2024-02-02
text: CRAN release: 2024-02-03 - “Wondering Continents”

title: rgplates 0.4.0 - 2024-02-02
text: New suggested package ‘httr2’ used online method (see changed), allows customized usage HTTP requests. argument reconstruct(), providing explicit support forward reconstruction. argumentation !=0, age=0 (default), calculates present-day coordinates past coordinates. argumentation !=0, age!=0 calculates shifted positions coordinates different times (age) original (). Support missing values (NA) point reconstructions, longer trigger error, rather propagated pipeline missing values. warn argument reconstruct(), allowing users switch warnings indicate paleocoordinates partitioning polygons. anchor argument reconstruct(), allowing users change anchor plate online submodule. necessary toggling paleomagnetic reference frame "TorsvikCocks2017" model GWS. former plateperiod (now: validtime) argument usable GPlates Web Service online reconstruction method.

title: rgplates 0.4.0 - 2024-02-02
text: Online reconstruction method (GWS) now uses HTTP POST method points sends coordinates form data. Internals changed accordingly. allows processing theoretically unlimited number coordinates. Online reconstruction method (GWS) longer bound integer ages. Point reconstruction results (matrix data.frame objects) now consistently column names paleolong paleolat past coordinates, long lat present-day coordinates. plateperiod argument renamed validtime better semantic compatibility GPlates Web Service.

title: rgplates 0.4.0 - 2024-02-02
text: Online reconstruction working package attached due issue checking valid input.

title: rgplates 0.4.0 - 2024-02-02
text: ‘chunk’ argument reconstruct() deprecacted scheduled omission.

title: rgplates 0.3.2 - 2023-09-06
text: CRAN release: 2023-09-06

title: rgplates 0.3.2 - 2023-09-06
text: Bug fix windows paths offline reconstruction methods

title: rgplates 0.3.1 - 2023-08-09
text: CRAN release: 2023-08-09

title: rgplates 0.3.1 - 2023-08-09
text: gws data object includes details reconstructable features GPlates Web services Routines check user entry GPlates Web Service gws Object. platemodel class now accepts feature descriptions data.frame. allows inclusion valid age ranges reconstruction feature collections. Simon Williams contributor, code basis accessing GWS import utils::data()

title: rgplates 0.3.1 - 2023-08-09
text: Minor bug allow topological features reconstructed. Minor bug occurred enumerate=FALSE cases target age included NAs error occurred plateperiod=TRUE, target age went beyond duration plates coordinates returned GPlates Desktop Application.

title: rgplates 0.3.0 - 2023-06-29
text: CRAN release: 2023-06-29

title: rgplates 0.3.0 - 2023-06-29
text: platemodel class now accepts multiple feature collections. can recontructed setting x argument recontruct().

title: rgplates 0.3.0 - 2023-06-29
text: interface reconstruct() function now matches GPlates web service. Use "static_polygons" instead "plates". plateperiod argument reconstruct() now defaults TRUE Documentation reflect models avialble GPlates web service Changed default method online reconstruction "MERDITH2021"

title: rgplates 0.3.0 - 2023-06-29
text: unnecessary imports utils

title: rgplates 0.2.0 - 2022-09-19
text: CRAN release: 2022-09-19

title: rgplates 0.2.0 - 2022-09-19
text: Package now depends sustainable ‘sf’-based interface GPLates Defense non-integer reconstruction dates online method. Support ‘sf’ type objects online reconstruction method defense decimal ages online reconstruction method. Support ’Spatial*’ objects (sp) offline reconstruction method ‘gmeta’ argument local reconstruction submodule sf output.

title: rgplates 0.2.0 - 2022-09-19
text: spatial outputs now default sf instead Spatial* types online reconstruction method now suggests ‘geojsonsf’ extension package reading features

title: rgplates 0.2.0 - 2022-09-19
text: dependency deprecated ‘rgdal’ extension Support polygons online reconstruction method.

title: rgplates 0.2.0 - 2022-09-19
text: Matrix-based reconstructinos accept missing values.
